seg.output: Grace from the Lord, dearest brothers. We have heard from our homeland, Zurich, that things are always worse in the present than in the past. It is said everywhere with a constant rumor that a few days ago it was reported to your city's senate and people and it was voted on whether you wanted to abolish or restore the Mass. We received this for certain today from the brothers of Basel, exhorting us to Constance. If this has happened in Zurich, which I hardly believe, where Christ has been preached with such faith and truth for almost fifteen years now, what do you expect will happen with us, who have hardly tasted Christ and his word, and where the fruit of the sown seed easily perishes? Alas, to whom does the labor of this or the business, nay, the tears, not cease? If these things are not true, as I am greatly hoping, it will be up to you, dearest brothers, to do this one thing with all your strength and work, that the status of your Zurich may be known by all, and that this empty rumor and the stain which unjustly marks Zurich may be uprooted and erased. I beg, entreat, and demand only this from you, dearest brothers.

seg.output: Things are always worse than what we hear from our homeland, Zurich. For it is widely said that recently a report was made to your senate and people, and it was decided by vote whether you wanted to abolish or restore the mass. Today, we have certainly heard from our Basel brothers urging us to be steadfast. If this happened in Zurich, as I do not believe, what do you expect will happen here, where we have barely tasted Christ and the Word of God, and where the fruit of the sown seed easily perishes? Oh God and people, who does not suffer the labor or the business, or even the tears? If this is not true, as I am greatly hoping, it is your duty, dear brothers, to investigate this matter with all your might and effort, so that all may know the state of your Zurich affairs, and this vain rumor and slander against Zurich be abolished and wiped out. I implore, I beseech, and I demand this of you, my dear brothers. For surely you will bring great honor to yourselves, the fruit of the Lord's word and work, and comfort to all the pious. You will restore courage to all the friends of Christ in our land, and shut the mouths of the wicked who would spread slander or curses. That you may have a fitting opportunity, you should present the letters you recently sent to the senate, and the reply I have sent here, if it is allowed with the consent of the senate.

seg.output:
We have heard from our homeland, Zurich, that things are always worse afterwards than before. For it is said everywhere with constant rumor that a short time ago it was reported to your Senate and people and acted upon by their votes, whether you want the Mass abolished or restored. We have certainly received this today from our brothers in Basel, exhorting us to stand firm. If this has been done in Zurich, as I do not believe, where for almost fifteen years now Christ has been preached with such faith and truth, what do you expect to happen among us, who have hardly tasted Christ and His Word, and among whom the fruit of the sown seed more easily perishes? Oh Heavens and men, who can escape this labour and business, nay, these tears? If this is not true, as I am filled with great hope, and that for many reasons not to be written here, it is for you, beloved brothers, to take great pains that the state of your Zurich affairs may be made known to all, and that this vain and groundless rumour, whereby Zurich is unjustly stigmatised, may be banished and removed. I pray, beseech and urge this one thing of you, beloved brothers. You will surely gain great praise from it, and a harvest for the Lord's Word and business, and comfort for all the pious. For you will give heart to all the friends of Christ in our country, and shut the mouths of the impious for slandering and reviling. To this end you have a sufficiently suitable opportunity, to commit to paper the exhortations which you lately sent to your Senate, and the apology which I herewith submit to you, if it be allowed by the consent of the Senate. If you think this good, you will take care to examine more diligently my rash writings. Come to the aid of the Church in her distress (if Christ and His Word is still in the world among you), I entreat you, beloved brothers.
From Bern, 1st April, 1532.
Your C. Megander.
To Utinger, Leo Jud, D. Engelhard and Bullinger, in Zurich, his beloved brothers.
